I.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
1.  The proposed West Bengal Public Finance Management Reforms Program of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) seeks to keep improving operational efficiencies, resource planning 
and  management,  and  service  delivery  in  West  Bengal  by  taking  a  whole-of-government 
approach to public financial management (PFM). 
 
2.  The rationale of the program is to create fiscal space and improve public service delivery 
by  (i)  extending the  reforms  undertaken  under  earlier  programs to  other  departments  and 
parastatals;1 (ii) upgrading the integrated financial management system (IFMS) and linking it with 
the financial management systems of other agencies, such as the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) 
and  West  Bengal's  Office  of  the  Principal  Accountant  General  (PAG);  (iii)  automating  the 
management of projects and public works; (iv) improving the availability of information for more 
effective service delivery; and (iv) continuously building the PFM capacities of state government 
and parastatal employees.  
 
3.  The effect of the reforms will be stronger operational efficiency of the Government of West 
Bengal’s PFM system, which will link the state Finance Department, parastatals, and external 
agencies (RBI and PAG). It will be achieved through the following reform areas: (i) automated 
and integrated systems for better management of social protection benefits, and grants to 
parastatals; (ii) improved resource planning, management, and control; and (iii) more effective 
information management and service delivery.2 
 
4.  Based on the development financing requirements of the policy reform program, the 
Government of India requested a regular loan of $50 million from ADB’s ordinary capital resources 
to help finance the program. The loan will have a 15-year term, including a grace period of 3 years, 
an annual interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate 
(LIBOR)-based lending facility, a commitment charge of 0.15% per year, and such other terms 
and conditions set forth in the draft loan and program agreements. There is no maturity premium 
payable to ADB. The central government will on-lend to the state government the local currency 
generated from the proceeds of the loan in accordance with its arrangement for the transfer of 
external assistance. Two tranches of $25 million each are envisaged: the first one disbursed upon 
loan effectiveness and the second one 24 months after the first tranche, or upon achievement of 
the second-tranche policy actions agreed by the state government.  
 
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
5.  The attached transaction technical assistance (TA) is being processed at the request of 
the state Finance Department to support the effective implementation of the program, including 
capacity building, and help ensure compliance with the second-tranche policy actions.3  
 
 
 
 
1 Parastatals are supported wholly or partially through grants from the state’s budget and include educational 
institutions, statutory boards and corporations, and local governments (urban and rural local bodies). 
2  The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1 and the policy matrix is in Appendix 4 of the Report and 
Recommendation of the President. 
3  The TA is included in ADB. 2019. Country Operations Business Plan: India, 2020–2022. Manila.

2 
B.  Outputs and Activities  
 
6.  Output 1: Actions to upgrade, integrate, and expand the IFMS monitored. This will 
involve 
(i)  upgrading the IFMS, such as adding new features in the government receipt portal 
system; 
(ii)  adding  new  IFMS  modules  for  (a)  procurement  and  contract  management, 
(b) project management, and (c) public works accounting; 
(iii)  customizing the IFMS for the integration of parastatals and urban local bodies 
(ULBs), which includes rolling out ePension management and eProvident fund 
management systems in parastatals and ULBs; 
(iv)  developing an online system for the electronic approval of schemes and the 
monitoring of grants-in-aid to ULBs and parastatals; 
(v)  integrating the IFMS with PAG's system for the management of state government 
pensions and submission of monthly accounts;  
(vi)  integrating  the  IFMS  with  the  RBI's  upgraded  eKuber  system  for  ePayment 
transactions; 
(vii)  developing a comprehensive management information system;  
(viii)  developing a web-based grievance redress system for all transport corporations 
and at least 5 ULBs; and 
(ix)  strengthening the gender aspects in all of the above activities. 
 
7.  Output 2: Gender-responsive medium-term expenditure framework developed. The 
TA will support the preparation of a gender-responsive medium-term expenditure framework 
(MTEF) by the Department of Women and Child Development and Social Welfare. The MTEF will 
be linked with the budget for FY2022. A gender impact assessment will be conducted of at least 
two of the department's schemes. 
 
8.  Output 3: Social and gender aspects strengthened. This will include building capacity 
for (i) obtaining and analyzing disaggregated data on various aspects of social and gender 
inclusion, such as males, females, transgenders, scheduled castes, scheduled tribes, and other 
backward castes as part of actions included in the program; and (ii) gender-responsive budgeting. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
9.  The TA is estimated to cost $400,000, of which $350,000 will be financed on a grant basis 
by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The state government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff remuneration, office accommodation 
and supplies, local transport, other logistical support, and other in-kind contributions. The key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 1. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
10.  ADB will administer the TA. The Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division 
of  its  South  Asia  Department  will  select,  supervise,  and  evaluate  the  consultants.  The 
implementation arrangements for the TA will be aligned with those of the proposed program. The 
state Finance Department will carry out the overall supervision and coordination. Consulting 
services totaling 17 person-months (national) will be required intermittently. The TA is estimated 
to begin in December 2020 and be completed in December 2022.

11.  Consulting services. ADB will engage a  consulting firm to provide national consultants 
using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a standard quality–cost ratio of 90:10. 
ADB will engage the consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy and Regulations (2017, 
as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff 
instructions.4 Lump-sum payments and output-based contracts will be considered for the TA 
consulting services. All disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to time).
